results.title: The Question of causation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
Studies the idea that causation is only one of many possible explanations for strong statistical correlations. Others may be common responses to a third factor, a confounding factor or coincidence. We are shown the importance of lurking variables, and Simpson’s paradox. As an example of the way in which evidence for causation is gathered when experiments cannot be done, the video presents an historical documentary on smoking and lung cancer. Presented by Theresa M. Amabile.

results.title: Correlation
results.creator_credit: Jill Singer, American Statistical Association, Chedd-Angier Productions and COMAP
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Against all odds: inside statistics”.
This program looks at the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables, by interpreting correlations, deriving the correlation co-efficient, and correlation and regression. Examples used are the relationship between twins’ personality and whether they were raised together or apart, and the relationship between baseball home runs and players’ salaries.

results.title: The Business file.
results.creator_credit: Paul Bosner and Dallas County Community College
results.brief_description: Hosted by Alex Burton this series of four educational films deals with various topics related to marketing. Each program interviews academic experts on theory and then takes the example of one company’s approach to the topic in hand.

results.title: Marketing: distribution strategy
results.creator_credit: Paul Bosner and Dallas County Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Business file.”.
Alex Burton questions Professors John Coyle and Donald Bowersox on product distribution as part of the marketing mix. Distribution is defined as putting the right product in the right place at the right time in the right quantity and is essential in the provision of customer service. Simple and complex distribution channels are described, some involving many “middle men” and some involving only the supplier and the customer. The managing director of Celestial Seasonings then describes the problems of distribution and how he has solved them.

results.title: Narritjin Maymuru (A)
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Narritjin Maymuru is a respected aboriginal artist. This series of films profiles the man and his work, as well as looking at the traditional way of life he and his family follow at Djarrakpi near Yirrkala in the Northern Territory. Photography is by Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia

results.title: Narritjin in Canberra
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
The film shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their ANU studio and later an exhibition of their work. In 1978 Narritjin Maymuru and his son Banapana were awarded fellowships as Visiting Artists to the Faculty of Arts at the Australian National University in Canberra. This program shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their A.N.U. studio. With anthropologist Howard Morphy, Narritjin conducts a seminar session for anthropology students. He explains his technique of bark painting and discusses some of the meanings behind the paintings. At the end of their stay in Canberra, Narritjin and Banapana hold an exhibition of their Manggalili art.

results.title: Narritjin at Djarrakpi. Part 2 (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
This program continues the life of Narritjin and his family at his clan settlement at Djarrakpi. Throughout Narritjin tells of his feelings about Djarrakpi and of his hopes for the future. A continuation of the study of the life of Narritjin and his family at his clan settlement at Djarrakpi, where they live largely off the land and the sea, producing bark paintings and craftwork to sell at Yirrkala. Gives an insight into Narritjin’s family life and his role as an educator to his sons.

results.title: Narritjin at Djarrakpi. Part 1 (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
Narritjin Maymuru and his family are establishing a small settlement at Djarrakpi, an important Manggalili clan site on the northern head of Blue Mud Bay in the Northern Territory. Narritjin is a renowned artist and he and his family produce bark paintings and craft work to sell at Yirrkala. This program, together with Part 2 [507335], gives an insight into Narritjin’s family life and, through his paintings, his role as an educator, teaching his sons about their clan land and its ancestral history.

results.title: My country, Djarrakpi
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
In this program, Narritjin Maymuru talks about his land at Djarrakpi, one of the most important sacred sites of his Manggalili clan. The film is set into two contrasting contexts. At an exhibition of his paintings at the Australian National University in Canberra, Narritjin explains the meaning behind a bark painting of Djarrakpi; then on the wind-swept sand dunes of Djarrakpi itself he explains the significance of some of the actual features of the landscape. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.description:

results.title: At the canoe camp
results.creator_credit: Philip Robertson, Ian Dunlop and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
Narritjin Maymuru is leader of the Manggalili clan of northeast Arnhem Land. Covers the daily life of Narritjin and his family at a camp in the bush. Shows the making of dug out canoes. Photography by Dean Semler.
